TITLE: Labor Board Proposes to Increase Legal Exposure for Franchised Chains
SUMMARY: The move would make companies liable for labor law violations by franchise holders, an issue that has shifted with White House control.

TITLE: Biden Administration Releases Plan for $50 Billion Investment in Chips
SUMMARY: The Commerce Department issued guidelines for companies angling to receive federal funding aimed at bolstering the domestic semiconductor industry.

TITLE: EU Leaders Say Putin’s Gas Power Is Weakening
SUMMARY: In Germany and elsewhere, leaders are growing more confident that months of work to stockpile and line up alternate energy sources may help them blunt Russia’s weaponization of exports.

TITLE: From Boom to Gloom: Tech Recruiters Struggle to Find Work
SUMMARY: As tech companies slow hiring and lay off workers, once-busy recruiters are shifting to other roles and cutting their rates.

SUMMARY: A drought that has crippled economic activity in southwestern China hints at the kind of disruption that climate change could wreak on global supply chains.

SUMMARY: The threat to Europe’s industrial might and living standards is particularly acute as policymakers race to decouple the continent from Russia’s power sources.

SUMMARY: Sales of electric cars are surging as more people become interested in the technology and grow concerned about climate change.

SUMMARY: In Michigan, Janet L. Yellen, the Treasury secretary, said investments made by Democrats would reshape the U.S. economy.

SUMMARY: Since 2020, four dozen pilot programs have started, with Los Angeles running one of the largest to provide cash assistance.

TITLE: Who Are America’s Missing Workers?
SUMMARY: The labor market appears hot, but the share of people who are either working or actively looking for a job still hasn’t quite recovered.

SUMMARY: A measure that accounts for all federal subsidies showed that fewer people experienced severe economic hardship, while health insurance coverage rose.

SUMMARY: Administration officials are pushing for a settlement to head off a walkout by tens of thousands of workers on Friday.

SUMMARY: The president is trying once again to accentuate the positives in the recovery from recession, but stubbornly high prices are complicating the message.

SUMMARY: A measure that accounts for all federal subsidies also showed a reduction of almost half in the number of children below the poverty level.

TITLE: Inflation Came in Faster Than Expected in August Even as Gas Prices Fell
SUMMARY: Overall inflation moderated less than anticipated, and a closely watched measure of price pressures jumped, bad news for the Federal Reserve.

SUMMARY: Employees say the inflexibility of scheduling upended their personal lives. The companies say they maintained service while using fewer resources.

SUMMARY: Inflation is less about pandemic and war surprises and more about economic momentum. That could make the solution more painful.

SUMMARY: The Biden administration is considering executive action to try to avoid a shutdown of the nation’s rail network that would harm the economy ahead of the midterm elections.

SUMMARY: Many families can borrow most of the cost of college using a Parent PLUS loan. This will not end well.

SUMMARY: Officials from the Group of 7 are striving to strike a delicate balance that encourages Russia to keep pumping oil but to sell it at a discount.

TITLE: Egypt Feels Pain of Global Disruptions Wrought by War and Pandemic
SUMMARY: The country’s economy has been very hard hit by cascading crises which have disrupted worldwide trade.

SUMMARY: Wall Street will watch the central bank’s economic forecasts closely on Wednesday, when another jumbo-size rate increase is expected.

SUMMARY: Italy’s largest refinery, owned by Russia’s Lukoil, has lost financing because of sanctions. Now, it faces the cutoff of its crude supply, putting thousands of jobs at risk.

SUMMARY: How easily companies give up swollen profits could determine how easily the Federal Reserve can cool inflation. Dealerships offer clues.

SUMMARY: Federal Reserve officials made another large rate increase and signaled more to come, pledging to quash inflation despite expected pain.

SUMMARY: National Labor Relations Board officials said the company had applied its workplace rules unfairly, and asked it to change or scrap the regulations.

SUMMARY: Federal Reserve officials and their counterparts around the world are trying to defeat inflation by rapidly raising interest rates. They know it will come at a cost.

SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve may have no choice but to wage a relentless inflation fight, but countries rich and poor are feeling the pain of plunging currencies.

SUMMARY: U.S. manufacturing is experiencing a rebound, with companies adding workers amid high consumer demand for products.

SUMMARY: The Bank of England had to step in Wednesday after markets deemed a new government economic plan unwise, but the pound has been on a longer slide.

SUMMARY: Scott Galloway chronicles a decades-long crisis using graphs, data and some provocative hypotheses.

SUMMARY: Inflation stayed far above the Federal Reserve’s goal in August, as prices climbed more quickly than economists expected.

SUMMARY: Unemployment is low, and hiring is strong. But there are signs that frenzied turnover and rapid wage growth are abating.

SUMMARY: America’s borrowing binge has long been viewed as sustainable because of historically low interest rates. But as rates rise, the nation’s fiscal woes are getting worse.

SUMMARY: The Bank of England stepped in to save a critical market this week. Economists say it was necessary but also worry about the precedent.

SUMMARY: Government data showed 10.1 million openings, a decline from 11.2 million in July. Overall hiring, quitting and layoffs were fairly steady.

SUMMARY: America’s borrowing binge has long been viewed as sustainable because of historically low interest rates. But as rates rise, the nation’s fiscal woes are getting worse.

SUMMARY: Central bankers have been raising rates rapidly to temper demand and bring prices under control. Now, they’re asking when they can slow down.

SUMMARY: The White House issued sweeping restrictions on selling semiconductors and chip-making equipment to China, an attempt to curb the country’s access to critical technologies.

SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve, like many central banks, sets policy with an eye on the domestic economy. Its battle to control prices is causing pain abroad.

SUMMARY: President Biden traveled to Poughkeepsie, N.Y., to connect a $20 billion investment by IBM to the bipartisan bill meant to spur production of critical microchips.

SUMMARY: The gain of 263,000 was shy of recent monthly totals but still robust. Stocks fell on fears of a harder, longer Fed campaign to fight inflation.

SUMMARY: Several municipalities in California’s Inland Empire, a logistics hub, have halted warehouse construction to study their impact on pollution and congestion.

SUMMARY: After an earlier announcement sent markets into a tailspin, the prime minister and the chancellor are under pressure to restore fiscal credibility.

SUMMARY: A proposed rule, long awaited by labor activists, would make it harder for companies to classify workers as independent contractors.

SUMMARY: U.S. officials pushed to choke off China’s access to critical semiconductor technology after internal debates and tough negotiations with allies.

SUMMARY: Where the markets go from here depends on whether and how deftly the Federal Reserve pivots from its hawkish stance.

SUMMARY: Seniors didn’t fare as well through the pandemic as most. But longer-term trends aren’t moving in their favor either.

SUMMARY: Jeremy Hunt also put a time limit on energy subsidies, seeking to reassure markets and reduce pressure on Prime Minister Liz Truss.

SUMMARY: Retailers have navigated pandemic closures and supply chain snarls in recent years. But dealing with the fallout from inflation could be an even tougher test.

SUMMARY: Federal Reserve and White House officials spent last week quizzing investors and economists about the risks of a British-style meltdown at home.

SUMMARY: Federal Reserve and White House officials spent last week quizzing investors and economists about the risks of a British-style meltdown at home.

SUMMARY: Scotch whisky exports have soared this year. The weak British pound could spur even more demand for single malt scotch.
